Award.AwardTitle: Protein analysis by desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Andre Venter at Western Michigan University to investigate various methods to improve the analysis of protein molecules by desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (DESI-MS). Imaging of tissue samples by DESI is an important new tool to aid in biological tissue imaging. DESI-imaging applications are currently limited to the analysis of small molecules such as lipids, fatty acids, and small molecules. Developing the ability to analyze proteins would extend the capabilities of imaging DESI-MS to determine the spatial distribution of proteins in biological relevant tissues. In addition, Professor Venter will make significant efforts to increase participation of undergraduate students, especially from underrepresented groups in research, and educate the general public about the importance of chemistry in their everyday life through collaboration with the Gwen Frostic School of Art at WMU.

Currently when proteins are analyzed by DESI-MS, sensitivity decreases with increasing molecular weight, and poor protein dissolution has been implicated as the major cause. Methods to improve dissolution and desorption such as the application of heat, the addition of a variety of additives to the DESI spray and a delayed desorption DESI sprayer will be investigated separately and in combination. To decipher mechanistic aspects of these mitigation strategies, Professor Venter will separately investigate the effects on dissolution of each, during desorption and ionization by using their previously developed Spray Desorption Collection, and Reflective Electrospray Ionization methods. Construction and characterization of a dual-sprayer DESI configuration will be carried out to determine optimum delay between localized surface wetting and desorption to maximize signal to noise ratios of proteins during DESI analysis, while conserving lateral resolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) and other ambient ionization methods allow for the analysis of samples directly from the natural environment with minimal sample preparation. This remarkable ability is the consequence of energetic desorption processes that substitute for the usual labor intensive and lengthy off-line sample preparation steps that precedes most chemical analyses. Processes of bulk extraction, dissolution, and dilution occur instead instantaneously and proximal to the mass spectrometer during ion production.  Mass spectrometers depend on the creation of ions to identify and quantify molecules. 

By making sample preparation part of the ionization process from a small micro-localized position on a sample, allows for the determination of the chemical distribution of molecules across sample surfaces. This retention of spatial information delivers benefits in biomedical and many other fields where important information is lost during the homogenization and extraction of bulk sample materials. 

DESI-MS has been used for such chemical microscopy studies to determine distribution and abundances and of small molecules such as lipids, metabolites and pharmaceuticals. Unfortunately, the analysis of protein molecules by desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (DESI-MS) is considered impractical due to a loss in sensitivity with increase in protein molecular mass, and DESI is only useful for biopolymers with molecular masses below around 25kDa. This is surprising and unfortunate considering that the ionization mechanism employed in DESI, electrospray ionization, has unsurpassed ability to ionize massive molecules and even intact viruses. 

Previously we demonstrated that the mass dependent loss in sensitivity of DESI to analyze proteins is likely the consequence of increasingly slow dissolving processes and the short timeframe for these processes to occur. Therefor the work supported under this award aimed to improve the ability of DESI to analyze larger proteins by investigating several approaches to improve protein dissolution or to increase the time available for this to occur:

  • The rate of dissolution frequently increases with temperature. In the case of DESI-MS of proteins, mild temperature increases under which proteins remain stable, was unable to mitigate the problem and only improved protein signal by 10%.
  • Various additives were investigated to promote protein solubility.  The use of millimolar concentrations of ammonium bicarbonate was very effective at increasing the signal to noise ratios for proteins with higher isoelectric points (pI), but not for those with low pI. 
  • The amino acid L-serine was also a very successful solution additive and was able to improve protein signal intensities by factors of 4 or more. Another and separate benefit to the addition of serine is its ability to remove alkali-metal adduction and to detect protein from solutions containing even 10 milimolar concentrations of sodium chloride.
  • A device was constructed that allows for delaying desorption after prewetting the sample by applying a small and micro-localized amount of solvent in-line with the DESI-desorption sprayer. This device not only improves the detection of proteins, but also allows for the ability to add two usually unmixable solvent additives into the analysis simultaneously, such as formic acid and the basic compound, ammonium bicarbonate. 
  • Enclosing the DESI desorption region allows for altering the atmosphere surrounding the desorption and ionization region. By entraining for example ethyl acetate vapors into enclosure, the intensities of protein peaks could be improved by a factor of four.

 Combining these approaches together with each other and with other techniques, such as ion mobility in tandem with mass spectrometry, will allow for improved protein analysis at higher sensitivity and over larger size ranges, directly from biological samples such as microcryotomed animal tissue slices and biopsies. 

 

 The STEAM Chemistry and the Arts Collaboration project, funded by this award,  brought together students from the Gwen Frostic School of Art, School of Music and the  Department of Chemistry at WMU. It challenged the groups to develop original works of art based on analysis by mass spectrometry. While increased participation of minorities in STEM fields is seen as national priority, many educators emphasize the importance of arts in preparing students for careers and helping spur discovery and innovation, thus we advocate for expanding the acronym to STEAM, emphasizing the importance of the arts. The STEAM Collaboration allows students to work closely in groups, each comprised of a chemist, a visual artist and a composer. The teams conceptualize an experiment, interpret data into art and ultimately present that art in a community exhibition. From polluted Kalamazoo river water to honey to coffee beans, students collected samples and then went to work first in a chemistry lab, then in the arts studios. The students developed communication skills, not only within their teams, but also in communicating science to a broader audience and thereby improving science literacy within the Kalamazoo community.
